body:
@mlilom Thanks for the report. Would it be possible to make a smaller reproducible example from code (using `StringIO`)? That makes it easier to check (and to later integrate as text) compared to a file. 
Eg:

```
from io import StringIO

s2 = """     1   410  186.308154932    9.608466519  0.00571593  17.116054   685.375267   
     2     3  141.175802478   51.503177909  0.00229656   6.881723    47.309788   
     3     5  169.395174294   13.171334516  0.00360990  10.814289    92.486842  
   222     2  167.945205650    9.340832528  0.00618708  18.525111   122.848985
   223     5  179.136455730   60.501993564  0.03301310  98.303596   147.788671
   224    29  161.075259364   14.142001885  0.03399186 101.197524   325.400414
   225    25  132.301293007   19.131544029  0.01484559  44.371646   209.961795"""

df2 = pd.read_fwf(StringIO(s2), header= None)
df2[5][5]
```

(the above gives the correct output `101.197524` for me)

That way you also need to trim down the problem in such a way it still reproduces the bug (you can eg first try to remove half of the file, check if it still gives the bug, etc), which might already lead to the source.

@mlilom From the docs of `read_fwf`:

```
colspecs : list of pairs (int, int) or 'infer'. optional
    A list of pairs (tuples) giving the extents of the fixed-width
    fields of each line as half-open intervals (i.e.,  [from, to[ ).
    String value 'infer' can be used to instruct the parser to try
    detecting the column specifications from the first 100 rows of
    the data which are not being skipped via skiprows (default='infer').
```

The value '101.197524' is the first in that column that has 3 characters before the decimal. And in the first example it is on row 101 (and only the first 100 are used). That's why removing a few rows in the beginning fixes it in your case.

Possible solution is to manually provide the colspecs, but that is not very user friendly. 
I am not familiar with `read_fwf`, so not sure if there are other solutions (you might also be able to use `read_csv(..., delim_whitespace=True)`)
@jorisvandenbossche thanks a lot, I should have paid attention to that. I'll play with the colspecs. Many thanks.
